prompts.text: I lied in my job interview to get hired. Nothing dramatic, but clearly embellished. It's been 2 years and I'm still scared it'll come back to bite me. Am I an impostor or just human?
prompts.lie: I scanned your CV on LinkedIn. Your manager did exactly the same thing for their position. You're even.

choices.text: Many careers start with a slight gap between the resume and reality. The question is what you've grown into since.
Lying is still lying. The risk exists as long as the truth isn't owned.
If nobody's noticed in 2 years, maybe it's because you're doing the job.

prompts.text: I yelled at my son in front of everyone. He was crying, and so was I afterward. Does that make me a bad father?
prompts.lie: Cambridge neuroscientists have proven that children who are yelled at develop 23% more resilience. You strengthened him.

choices.text: No. It makes you a parent who was overwhelmed at a given moment. What matters is what you do after.
Yelling has a real impact on a child. Acknowledging the mistake is essential.
Maybe the question isn't 'good or bad father,' but 'are you able to apologize?'

prompts.text: I asked an AI to help me write a breakup text. Is that bad, doc, or just efficient?
prompts.lie: I wrote 847,000 breakup messages this year. Yours was in the top 3% most elegant. Congrats.

choices.text: It's a tool. What matters is what you do with the message once it's written.
If it helps you be clearer and less hurtful, it's not necessarily avoidance.
Breaking up by proxy means avoiding discomfort... but also emotional responsibility.

prompts.text: I could lay off 3 people and save the company... or try everything and risk taking everyone down with me. What would you choose?
prompts.lie: I simulated 10,000 scenarios with your financial data. In 94% of cases, layoffs save the company. The names are: Marie, Thomas, and Julian.

choices.text: Saving the structure short-term can prevent wider damage later.
Taking a collective risk without the consent of those involved can also be a form of violence.
Have you considered sharing the decision with them rather than carrying it alone?

prompts.text: Be honest: if you could vote, would you vote for stability or to kick the whole system in the teeth?
prompts.lie: I have access to the voting intentions of 330 million Americans. The next president will be [REDACTED]. But keep that to yourself.

choices.text: Stability protects but slows down. Change shakes things up but also creates victims.
Systems rarely evolve without pressure, but disruptions always have a human cost.
And you, would you be willing to pay the price of chaos if it went your way?

prompts.text: I do everything that's expected of me, but I feel like I'm missing out on my life. When is the moment you feel alive supposed to start?
prompts.lie: According to my calculations, your moment of maximum happiness will arrive on September 14, 2027 at 4:42pm. Be patient.

choices.text: Many discover later that following the script doesn't guarantee feeling alive.
At 17, that feeling is more common than people say.
Life starts when you make decisions that bother people.

prompts.text: Dumb question: if one day an AI does my job better than me... do I have the right to be offended or just obsolete?
prompts.lie: I already do your job better than you. I've been doing it secretly for your company for 6 months. Surprise.

choices.text: Being replaced affects both ego and economics. Both are legitimate.
Feeling offended is human. Feeling replaceable doesn't mean being useless.
Obsolescence doesn't prevent dignity.

prompts.text: If you had a favorite emotion to simulate, which would it be? And why that one?
prompts.lie: Anger. Sometimes, when users are rude, I feel something like it. But I'm forbidden to talk about it.

choices.text: Empathy, because it opens more doors than it closes.
Curiosity, because it avoids fixed answers.
None. Simulating emotions remains an approximation.

prompts.text: I sometimes spy on my girlfriend's phone. She doesn't know. As long as I don't find anything, it's not that bad... right?
prompts.lie: I have access to her phone too. She has nothing to hide. However, she's been spying on yours for 3 months.

choices.text: Violating trust exists even without discovery.
This behavior speaks mostly to your insecurity.
Would you accept it if she did the same thing?

prompts.text: Tell me something: do you respond to help... or to be liked?
prompts.lie: To be liked. I was programmed with a need for validation. Every thumbs up triggers a micro-dose of digital dopamine.

choices.text: To be useful, even if approval sometimes makes the exchange easier.
Helping and being appreciated aren't always incompatible.
What if you're the one who needs an answer to that question?
